I'm guessing that if you haven't played it yet you don't intend to ;3 The CoD fandom has done a fairly thorough job of elucidating General Shepherd's relationship to Makarov, and the purpose of planting Allen and the evidence that an American aided the terrorist in order to go to war. But one thing they haven't done, at least to my knowledge, is examine Shepherd's relationship to Task Force 141. First off, we know that Shepherd is in command of TF141 - ostensibly because he is in command of all of the special operations forces in the area. How do we know this? Because he's in command of not only TF141, but the Army Rangers and Shadow Company, too. We know from S.S.D.D. that Shadow Company are Shepherd's handpicked elite; presumably American soldiers drawn from regiments like the 75th, just like Allen. So where does that leave the Task Force, if Shepherd already has his group of handpicked elites? Unlike Shadow Company, who all wear American flag patches, TF141 is international, consisting of most English-speaking NATO countries. Each of these soldiers answers to Shepherd, ostensibly, but would answer first to their respective armed forces. These aren't really "his" soldiers to begin with, he already has "his" elites, and furthermore none of the officers of TFT141 are American - they're British. You probably see where I'm going with this. Shepherd, again as we see in S.S.D.D., and a number of other levels, in commentary from Dunn, Foley (who does not contradict Dunn), the Task Force, and even the Air Force's refusal to comply with the letter of his commands, is not highly-regarded. He is known for his lack of value on his men's lives, something Dunn tells us explicitly and we see confirmed by his actions. This could well be a result of the events in MW1 - where we learn that Shepherd was in charge of the doomed incursion of Shock and Awe - or he could always have been like that. Either way, this is why he needs a private company of bodyguards. ((Tangent: one of the coolest things about MW2 was how Shadow Company had better and more evasive AI than the rest of your enemies. Must've been hell to program, but it was so worth it. Most games make enemies "harder" by giving them more damage input or absorption. But is that realistic in a shooter? Not really. IW's take was fantastic.)) So Shepherd doesn't command much loyalty from his own troops in the first place, he knows it, and these are foreign soldiers. I would think it's safe to say that Shepherd does not trust the Task Force long before they stop trusting him. And Shepherd's lack of trust is not misplaced. Soap is, I believe, and will attempt to support, simply using his resources to get what he really wants: Captain Price. Here's what tipped me off, and was never adequately explained in game: they infiltrate the gulag to free Prisoner 627 to use as "bait" to lure out Makarov, or so Soap says, but they never actually put his plan into action. In fact, they never even try to put this plan into action. Honestly, it doesn't seem like they ever intended to. As soon as Price is freed - in other words, after Soap has used the resources at Shepherd's command as a general in the US military to free Price - they immediately disregard his orders and rush off to do something else entirely. This is probably the single largest piece of evidence I can use in support of my theory: they never used Price the way they said they intended to, nor did they ever try. In fact, they lied about why Makarov might want "Prisoner 627": Price wasn't the one who killed Makarov's "hero" Zakhaev. Soap was. They had the "bait" all along. So at the very least Soap lied about that part, absolutely. It's possible that they dropped the "bait" idea because of who Prisoner 627 turned out to be, but nevertheless they still lied about why Makarov would want him. And why would they do that, unless they knew who Prisoner 627 was? Why would Soap fabricate a justification to retrieve that prisoner unless it was someone very important? Watch the video of their reunion again. There's no question that Price is shocked. But Soap? Emotional, sure. Certainly not astounded, even though this is clearly an amazing coincidence. Or it would be if this wasn't the whole point in the first place. (Of course it's reasonable to assume that the other members of the SAS in the Task Force, like Ghost, are in on it - they know who Price is, and Ghost was involved in Rojas' interrogation, and Ghost was in charge of locating Price at the gulag. Could this be because he knew what the questioning was really about, and who "Prisoner 627" might really be listed as?) But that's not all. The careful observer will notice that the route to Price has been marked ahead of time: play the level again, and look for those little green spray-painted boxes. Yes, they appear elsewhere in the series, but they're always there to mark a path. Who has done this in the middle of a Russian prison, and why? Why? Recall how MW1 ended. Price was not captured by the enemy that we saw on screen - the Loyalists, led by Kamarov, had flown in for the rescue. What happened after that isn't clear, possibly that he was taken on a different transport, but he was taken by Loyalists. And the Russian Civil War wasn't won by military force, we learn, but rather public opinion - it's entirely likely that those Loyalists are now with the Ultranationalists. Not in any positions of importance, of course. That's not where you'd put your political enemies, even if they are your fellow countrymen. Perhaps you'd put them somewhere out of the way - like Siberia. Something irrelevant and humiliating like guarding a prison in Siberia. Now, Price is known to these former Loyalists, and what's more so is Soap (and possibly Ghost). Which brings me to my next point: Soap spends an awful lot of time off-screen in Cliffhanger. Ostensibly supporting you from an elevated position, but in reality he stops doing that after one kill. And then beats you to the hangar even though you've supposedly had a head start. Once inside, whilst Roach gets the ostensible objective, the ACS module, Soap remains behind to tinker with the captured satellite. But why? What is he doing with it? Why was he already there when he told you he was providing you with overwatch (which he wasn't)? My answer: he's there to pick up the information a former Russian Loyalist has left him about Price's location. It would be dangerous if not impossible to get this information to him by any other means, but if he's just happened to sneak into Russia, how could it ever be traced? But hold the phone, what about Rojas? Why did they go all the way to South America? Well, for one, they needed an excuse to use Shepherd's resources to rescue Price. "Oh yeah, we just happened to know the guy who killed Zakhaev and where he is" wouldn't cut it - remember, Shepherd already mistrusts them. Remember who sends them after Rojas? It's Shepherd himself. Soap and the Task Force go along with it, with this plan in mind: no matter what Rojas tells them about Makarov, what Shepherd will learn is the location of a man who can draw him out. With nothing else to go on and no reason (yet) to doubt them, Shepherd agrees to it. I get the distinct impression that the British commanders (MacMillan?) tacitly, if not outright, approve of the "use American resources to rescue Price" plan, because not only is he one of their own, he's clearly picked up important intelligence while incarcerated. Like Russian nuclear launch codes. Notice that Soap doesn't even join you in Contingency, and the rest of the troops aren't informed of its purpose (see: Ghost flipping out over the launch). Plausible deniability. So, now the elite soldiers he didn't even trust in the first place have disobeyed a direct order and clearly lied to him - and Shepherd's itching to dispose of anyone who might tip his hand in the first place. This is why Shepherd "betrays" the Task Force, and tries to have them all killed. They're disloyal, they're dangerous, and they could undo everything. And he's already got his elites. In this light his actions make so much more sense. It was always about Price. (That leaves one last mystery of course - what is Craig Fairbrass doing in MW3? I sincerely doubt it's "some other random character, trolololo" and it's certainly not "generic British MP announcer #4" as he stated he was working on the game for three months. But who else could it be. This, combined with Robert Bowling's statement that Ghost "isn't exactly dead - you'll see" had many convinced that this was going to be a prequel game, but it isn't. Is it possible Ghost is still alive? Well, in a word: yes. He was shot in the chest with a high calibre round, true, but he was also wearing body armour. And we know from the no-clippers - the ones who showed us that Gaz was shot in the shoulder, not the back of the head - and the cutscene itself that Shepherd poured the gasoline mostly on Roach; only Ghost's arm was on fire. Toad and Archer were unaccounted for, so it's possible they doused the flames and provided medical aid. It's also possible, since Shepherd and Shadow Company left immediately afterward, that some of Makarov's men who weren't on the estate at the time arrived shortly, and now Ghost is their prisoner. And since the game ended with Price and Soap gunning for Makarov, it's possible they could encounter him there. It would certainly bring Makarov's ominous statement about how the enemy of my enemy is my friend "cuts both ways" to a poetic climax.)

To no one's surprise, I imagine, the whole "Tiger Mother" story certainly has made the rounds in my department, particularly in the wake of the article accusing some Canadian universities of being "Too Asian". Why has this been turned into an East versus West dichotomy? There are innumerable strict parents and high-achieving young people of European descent. My own parents would not accept anything below an A. For many of the rest of the top grade earners in my high school it was the same, regardless of background. Being naturally brilliant or disciplined cannot compete with someone who has the smarts and the work ethic; anyone with an ounce of sense knows this. The only criticism I have of Amy Chua's parenting method is her refusal to allow her daughters to participate in any sports. Not only do sports encourage a healthy and active lifestyle, they have been shown to improve the self-esteem and body image of children (particularly women and girls) and that this improvement lasts a lifetime. Also, non-participation in athletics precludes them from receiving a number of prestigious awards, including becoming Rhodes Scholars. (That said my parents refused to let me study art or music, viewing it as Amy Chua does athletics - a waste of my time better spent studying.) However, something those lauding her eldest daughter's acceptance to both Yale and Harvard have overlooked is this: both of her parents are Harvard Law alumni and Yale Law professors. Really? The daughter of not one but two Yale Law professors who graduated from Harvard was accepted to Yale and Harvard? You don't say. Not that it isn't an accomplishment to be admitted to these schools regardless, I'm sure, but between this and the elite private preparatory schools this girl's parents forked out for her to attend and the countless thousands of dollars funneled into her music lessons and academic tutoring that the mother admits she's had, this achievement somehow seems less than astounding. The girls themselves also admit that their upbringing wasn't as harsh as their mother has made it out to be in order to sell a book (also hardly shocking). Instead of asking themselves if their parenting is too Western or not Eastern enough, what parents should be asking themselves is this: -Is my child's education their first priority during their student years? (If no, it should be.) AND -Am I a Yale Law professor with a degree from Harvard and scads of money? (If no, your child's chances of getting into Yale may not be as high as Amy Chua's regardless of your parenting practices.)

I take it back. Demon's Souls is a lot of fun, once you get the hang of it. It requires a certain flair for cheapness, something that - if you're familiar with my versions of levels like Estate Takedown - I have in spades. Except that cheapness in Demon's Souls isn't just a bonus, it's mandatory. Setting yourself up in the one place on the map where you have line of sight but your enemy doesn't is often the only way to win. This game is built for you to find and manipulate flaws in the AI. Come to think of it, though, if I had to kill hordes of demons with a bow an arrow in real life? I'd do it from where they couldn't hit me back.

I have come to the depressing realization that 90% of what makes games like Demon's Souls (or even DMC3 or Shinobi for that matter) isn't the mastery of technical skills, but rather the lack of checkpoints. It is not that you must be able to beat all enemies, it is that you must be able to beat all enemies in any given sitting, at least once. This is what made the old platformers difficult (e.g. Mario) and even moreso if they gave you a limited number of lives to beat the entire game. Super Mario World, with its save points, was infinitely more enjoyable, because it meant that you did not have to beat the entire game in a single sitting. Save points are a necessity for grownups with jobs and other obligations, who might be called upon to put the controller down at any given moment. Similarly, if Demon's Souls had checkpoints, I'm sure I would have beaten it already. Of course, the lack of them, combined with the fact that you lose all progress (in the form of Soul Points) if you don't go back to the Nexus (and lose all physical progress in the level) once in a while to spend them before you die. This requires a certain level of mental and emotional discipline that games with checkpoint mechanics lack. The pure mechanical difficulty of these games is on par with any given, say, shooter (and probably less than some on their "hardest" modes, precisely because you don't lose all progress when you die and thus don't get as frustrated when you approach a given gunfight for the umpteenth time). Of course, in lieu of mental and emotional discipline, most people just end up farming. In their defense, I can see the appeal of replacing anguish with tedium. You live the way you want to live, I suppose.

There's been a fair bit published on gaming sites lately with respect to this topic, with people by and large clamouring to see more diversity in games: not just more female protagonists (though that's a large part of it), but also simply more protagonists that aren't blue-eyed brown-haired white men in their 30s. I wonder if this will result in real change; right now it's hard to tell. The defense these companies use for this decision is always "marketing" (if they bother to defend it at all). Even in games where you can play non-white, non-male protagonist, such as Mass Effect, the brown-haired white dude's the one on the box. But is this really the case? I should think not. The largest single demographic of console gamers is women between the ages of 18-24. Even if it wasn't, this defense is pure tripe - it's not as if Samus, or Mario, or Link sell any less because they're too young, too old, or too female. The insinuation that the 30-something white male is the most "relatable" is utterly insulting. A psychic Space Marine from the distant future isn't more relatable to me because he has a penis. I mentioned this problem to a roommate, who parroted that this decision was likely made because most gamers are white males. Now, this isn't even remotely true. Even leaving the Asian markets out of it, if women alone are 40% of console gamers, the racial diversity amongst male gamers put the "white male" well below a majority. How bitter and outright sulky he became when I pointed this out, however, was far more telling - far closer to the heart of the issue than "relatability". He is, of course, a 30-something white male. The mere thought that a protagonist that was exactly like him was not something he was rightfully owed - that he was not inherently the most "relatable" type of human being - was an unpleasant realization. That's the rub; our entire civilization is fraught with male and white privilege, and he's been taught that the vast majority of heroes will be exactly like him his entire life. Of course, you can't paint every 30-something white male with the same brush. Many of those are the ones clamouring for more diversity. My roommate himself prefers a female Shepard for precisely that reason. Another reason I think the "marketing" excuse is bunk is that, if most protagonists looked like me I would be good and tired of it by now myself. Sure, I'm not a man or transgendered or gay or Asian or what have you - but nor am I a psychic Space Marine. I don't have to play someone exactly like me. Heck, it's not as if I make characters that look like me when I can create my own protagonist. I'm a wimpy academic; my fem!Shep is an elite operator. As such she looks the part, complete with heavily muscled jaw, scars, and buzzcut. My male!Shep looks like a '70s porn star with a bad red dye job. Why? It looked hilarious. R6 Vegas - rightly, I think - doesn't give you a choice about making your elite operator look tough; s/he's going to be butch, but everything else is up to the imagination. My Bishop's got darker skin and black hair because it looks the most badass with cammoflage facepaint. My Fallout 3 protagonist is quirky, nerdy - she's got black skin and pink hair in pigtails. My Demon's Souls heroes are an Eastern albino Templar and a Southern Hunter. They don't have to look like me for me to relate to them. From what I've seen the 30-something white males I know are the same way. So why do we really have so many protagonists that look (and even more or less act) exactly the same way?

One thing I've noticed, having watched every installment of Extra Credits thus far? The CoD series makes it into the "doin' it right" category in virtually every episode (barring a few, such as "True Female Characters" for obvious reasons - though when they do feature female characters they're wearing historically or contemporarily accurate military fatigues and are as competent as anyone else, which is saying more than I can for most other shooters out there). This isn't just an 'in my opinion' thing - the EC folks mention CoD as an example to follow in everything from a good reward system, good pacing, good storytelling (Yahtzee agrees), good tutorials, and even good musical scoring. The latest one is particularly apt: I have always loved the CoD tutorials. The two CoD dev teams have different ideas about what makes a good tutorial, but in this case they're both right. It's a shooter; it isn't as if there are a lot of controls to master. Thus, Treyarch simply begins with a relatively easy mission in which your team heavily supports you. You learn by doing. I don't know of anyone who has complaints with this - if the opening mission is too difficult for you, you need to lower the difficulty. It's as simple as that. It lets experienced players start the action right away, too. Infinity Ward thinks differently. The Modern Warfare games have formal tutorial missions, but what makes them great tutorial missions is that they're still part of the narrative. In a much richer way than "Welcome to boot camp, private" - in MW and MW2 the tutorials introduce you to the characters you'll be close to for the remainder of the game - and their personalities - and serve to set up the basic plot. As the character maneuvers his way through training camp he hears snippets of dialogue from other characters, too, much of which is amusing, clever, or ominous. And the tutorial serves the function of testing the player's skills - based on their time in the introductory course, the game recommends a difficulty setting, which in my experience is fairly accurate (i.e. my pit scores were roughly in line with how I progressed from Regular, to Hardened, to Veteran). This tutorial can take several minutes if the player wants to experience absolutely everything in it, including easter eggs, but experienced players can not only blow through it in seconds if they choose, they can get trophies/achievements for superb times in the training run. This certainly kept my interest despite multiple playthroughs. It isn't skippable, but nor does it need to be. Anyone else got a tutorial they'd like to recommend? FF7 followed Treyarch's philosophy of simply starting with an easy mission (FF7, in my view, also has one of the greatest opening sequences of any video game - as did FF6). DSRK did it more like IW: teaching basic controls whilst establishing the mood, atmosphere, basic plot, and major characters (Raidou and Gouto). Chrono Trigger and Fallout 3 take a different tack altogether - these are vast, impressive games, and the introduction is long and story-rich, but still entertaining and full of player input that will be important later on, in order to immerse the player in the world they'll be experiencing for the next 50 hours or more. They do cover the basic mechanics as well, but you'll hardly have noticed. This simply wouldn't work in an explosive action thriller like CoD, nor would it work for a game like Nocturne where a sense of disorientation and unfamiliarity is key. God of War is, of course, famous for its tutorials - cinematic high points of the games that leave you eager for more. Any other noteworthy games you think should make this list?
